content: WASHINGTON – The Justice Department said Wednesday it would drop corruption charges against former Sen. Ted Stevens because it withheld evidence from the senator's defense team. The reversal is an embarrassing black eye for the Justice Department, which won a conviction against the Alaska Republican in October and is now asking to overturn it. Stevens, 85, the patriarch of Alaska politics since before statehood, lost his re-election bid in November and has been awaiting sentencing. He was the longest serving Republican senator. He was convicted of seven felony counts of lying on Senate financial disclosure forms to conceal hundreds of thousands of dollars in gifts and home renovations from a wealthy oil contractor. The trial was beset by government missteps, culminating recently when a federal judge took the unusual step of holding the Justice Department in contempt. In early morning court filings, the Justice Department admitted it never turned over notes from an interview with the oil contractor, who estimated the value of the renovation work as far less than he testified at trial. "I have determined that it is in the interest of justice to dismiss the indictment and not proceed with a new trial," Attorney General Eric Holder said in a statement released Wednesday. The Justice Department is investigating the conduct of the prosecutors who tried the Stevens case.
reply: WASHINGTON – The Justice Department said Wednesday it would drop corruption charges against former Sen. Ted Stevens because it withheld evidence from the senator's defense team. The reversal is an embarrassing black eye for the Justice Department, which won a conviction against the Alaska Republican in October and is now asking to overturn it. Stevens, 85, the patriarch of Alaska politics since before statehood, lost his re-election bid in November and has been awaiting sentencing. He was the longest serving Republican senator. He was convicted of seven felony counts of lying on Senate financial disclosure forms to conceal hundreds of thousands of dollars in gifts and home renovations from a wealthy oil contractor. The trial was beset by government missteps, culminating recently when a federal judge took the unusual step of holding the Justice Department in contempt. In early morning court filings, the Justice Department admitted it never turned over notes from an interview with the oil contractor, who estimated the value of the renovation work as far less than he testified at trial. "I have determined that it is in the interest of justice to dismiss the indictment and not proceed with a new trial," Attorney General Eric Holder said in a statement released Wednesday. The Justice Department is investigating the conduct of the prosecutors who tried the Stevens case.
title: US seeks to drop case against former Sen. Stevens

content: quote: Originally posted by samh32: "I have determined that it is in the interest of justice to dismiss the indictment and not proceed with a new trial," Attorney General Eric Holder said in a statement released Wednesday. I disagree with this decision because it leaves Stevens in limbo - it removes the guilty verdict without the option of providing another verdict in its place. If the evidence was incorrect or manufactured, say so. That way he is publicly exonerated. If you still think he is guilty, do a retrial (fairly this time) so that we can get a real verdict. This half-assed decision to just drop the case lets Repub's claim their guy was unjustly prosecuted while Dem's claim he got off easy! No resolution, and the American people (esp Alaskans) deserve one.
quote: Originally posted by samh32: "I have determined that it is in the interest of justice to dismiss the indictment and not proceed with a new trial," Attorney General Eric Holder said in a statement released Wednesday.

content: Honestly, I don't give a crap if there is a (R) or (D) after his name, this is unacceptable. If he did the crime, then he should be prosecuted and if found guilty sentenced. I would only add that his age and health SHOULD be taken into consideration when sentenced. Now, he's been given a pass and RIGHTLY SO. He was not given a fair trial in court. His lawyers were unable to present the full and complete defence that's guarenteed by the Constitution, The prosecuters screwed the pooch, wether intetnional or not. They should be investigated and held accountable. If it was an accident, they should be fired for incompetence, if by design, then have them brought up on charges. The DOJ and the courts are the LAST place partisan politics should be played.

content: The crux of the case was that Stevens got more than faIR VALUE for the work done, as he did pay the contractor some. The first statment of payments, under oath, showed fair valus paid. In court, work was magnified, payment minimized. Stevens was denied access to the first testimony, which was exculpatory in nature. This is illegal. Thus, there is great reluctance to re-try. After all, I'd call the prosecutors and make THEM explain why THEY railroaded me, wouldn't you? And so, case closed, much less embarassing.

content: WASHINGTON – The Justice Department said Wednesday it would drop corruption charges against former Sen. Ted Stevens because it withheld evidence from the senator's defense team. The reversal is an embarrassing black eye for the Justice Department, which won a conviction against the Alaska Republican in October and is now asking to overturn it. Stevens, 85, the patriarch of Alaska politics since before statehood, lost his re-election bid in November and has been awaiting sentencing. He was the longest serving Republican senator. He was convicted of seven felony counts of lying on Senate financial disclosure forms to conceal hundreds of thousands of dollars in gifts and home renovations from a wealthy oil contractor. The trial was beset by government missteps, culminating recently when a federal judge took the unusual step of holding the Justice Department in contempt. In early morning court filings, the Justice Department admitted it never turned over notes from an interview with the oil contractor, who estimated the value of the renovation work as far less than he testified at trial. "I have determined that it is in the interest of justice to dismiss the indictment and not proceed with a new trial," Attorney General Eric Holder said in a statement released Wednesday. The Justice Department is investigating the conduct of the prosecutors who tried the Stevens case.

content: quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: Holder is a hack. he is probably just setting up a precedent so he wont go after the corrupt turds on the left. BS the Republican Justice Department did not follow the rules, which is why the Judge delayed sentencing and censored the prosecutors from the REPUBLICAN Justice Department, it was because the probelms with the prosecution may have required a retrial, etc. that Mr Holder decided to drop the case. If actually seems based on the evidence already presented that Mr Stevens would LOSE a retrial but at his age with appeals and precedural motions, etc, he might not actually live long enough finish a retrial. Personally I think Mr Holder should also do a little extra for (to) the prosecutors who broke the rules in this case to show others that such conduct will not be accepted. For example an official reprimands on their records.
quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: Holder is a hack. he is probably just setting up a precedent so he wont go after the corrupt turds on the left.

Yeh, and that list is long of hacks on the left, that are not being tried with similar infractions. reid and his real estate deals, Dodd and his mortgage etc etc... Does that work for all crimes? Let off one murderer because another goes free? How about thieves? In dropping the case against Stevens without expressly indicating his innocence they have weakened the chances of going after other crooked politicians. Prosecute Stevens fairly, and then go after the rest of the *******s on both sides of the aisle. This crap of letting them go is one of the few ways the higher-ups in the parties genuinely do collude.

content: quote: Originally posted by samh32: quote: Originally posted by navy8086: Not condoning what he did, but at 85 ANY jail time would probably turn into a LIFE SENTENCE ! So in other words...No jail time for this guy as well! Probably not. quote: An analysis conducted by the Center for Responsive Politics found that Madoff and his wife, Ruth, gave the bulk of their campaign contributions to Democrats. The couple donated $238,200 to federal candidates, parties and committees since 1991, and Democrats received 88 percent of those donations. Madoff gave $11,400 to nine Republicans in the same time period. None of them is in office now.

content: Honestly, I don't give a crap if there is a (R) or (D) after his name, this is unacceptable. If he did the crime, then he should be prosecuted and if found guilty sentenced. I would only add that his age and health SHOULD be taken into consideration when sentenced. Now, he's been given a pass and RIGHTLY SO. He was not given a fair trial in court. His lawyers were unable to present the full and complete defence that's guarenteed by the Constitution, The prosecuters screwed the pooch, wether intetnional or not. They should be investigated and held accountable. If it was an accident, they should be fired for incompetence, if by design, then have them brought up on charges. The DOJ and the courts are the LAST place partisan politics should be played.
reply: Honestly, I don't give a crap if there is a (R) or (D) after his name, this is unacceptable. If he did the crime, then he should be prosecuted and if found guilty sentenced. I would only add that his age and health SHOULD be taken into consideration when sentenced. Now, he's been given a pass and RIGHTLY SO. He was not given a fair trial in court. His lawyers were unable to present the full and complete defence that's guarenteed by the Constitution, The prosecuters screwed the pooch, wether intetnional or not. They should be investigated and held accountable. If it was an accident, they should be fired for incompetence, if by design, then have them brought up on charges. The DOJ and the courts are the LAST place partisan politics should be played.

title: US seeks to drop case against former Sen. Stevens

content: The crux of the case was that Stevens got more than faIR VALUE for the work done, as he did pay the contractor some. The first statment of payments, under oath, showed fair valus paid. In court, work was magnified, payment minimized. Stevens was denied access to the first testimony, which was exculpatory in nature. This is illegal. Thus, there is great reluctance to re-try. After all, I'd call the prosecutors and make THEM explain why THEY railroaded me, wouldn't you? And so, case closed, much less embarassing.

content: Well D, our political biases makes us see what we think is happening. I'm guilty of such things(though I'll deny it! ) But, I tend to think of what happened with the Gotti trials, as somewhat similar here. The prosecution screwed up a couple times, until they got it right. The only reason they got it "right" is that they managed to keep Bruce Coutler(sp) out of the court room.
